title: 108_hr1672
content: The Act titled "Tax Credit for Charitable Contributions Act of 2003" introduces a credit for charitable contributions to certain private charities assisting the poor under section 25C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Tax Credit for Charitable Contributions Act of 2003 allows individuals to claim a tax credit for qualified charitable contributions made to eligible charities. The credit is limited to $100 for individuals and $200 for joint filers. Qualified charitable contributions must be made in cash and reported on the tax return. A qualified charity is defined as an organization that meets certain criteria. A qualified charity, as defined by the Tax Credit for Charitable Contributions Act of 2003, is an organization certified by the Secretary under section 501(c)(3), primarily assisting individuals with incomes below 150 percent of the official poverty line. The Tax Credit for Charitable Contributions Act of 2003 defines a qualified charity as an organization certified under section 501(c)(3) that primarily assists individuals with incomes below 150 percent of the official poverty line. An organization must ensure that its annual exempt purpose expenditures are at least 70 percent of its annual aggregate expenditures to meet the minimum expenditure requirement. The Tax Credit for Charitable Contributions Act of 2003 defines a qualified charity as an organization certified under section 501(c)(3) that primarily assists individuals with incomes below 150 percent of the official poverty line. Expenses that are not deductible include administrative expenses, expenses for influencing legislation, fundraising expenses, and litigation expenses on behalf of individuals. Contributions made by the taxpayer before the deadline for filing the tax return are treated as made on the last day of the taxable year. The Tax Credit for Charitable Contributions Act of 2003 defines a qualified charity as an organization certified under section 501(c)(3) that primarily assists individuals with incomes below 150 percent of the official poverty line. Contributions made by the taxpayer before the deadline for filing the tax return are treated as made on the last day of the taxable year. The credit provided for any qualified charitable contribution is in lieu of any deduction otherwise allowable under this chapter. A taxpayer may elect for any taxable year to have this section not apply. The maximum amount of credit is adjusted for inflation after 2003. The Tax Credit for Charitable Contributions Act of 2003 allows for an increase in the maximum amount of credit determined by substituting 'calendar year 2002' for 'calendar year 1992'. Any increase is rounded to the nearest multiple of $5. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart A of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The Tax Credit for Charitable Contributions Act of 2003 increases the maximum credit amount by substituting 'calendar year 2002' for 'calendar year 1992'. Contributions made after the 90th day following the enactment of this Act in taxable years ending after that date are eligible for the amendments made in this section.
